qas.question: Sprint, ITT, and Telenor are examples of what?
Who provides service to every City, town, and hamlet in Somalia?
aproximately how many main lines are there per 1000 people?
what is another word for availability of telephone lines?
How much does Hormuud Telecom gross per year?
Who offers the most expensive phone calls in Africa?
How much does the Somali Telecom Group gross per year?

plausible_answers.text: Somtel Network, Golis Telecom Group, Hormuud Telecom, Somafone, Nationlink, Netco, Telcom and Somali Telecom Group

qas.question: Which companies agreed to a deal that would limit competition?

plausible_answers.text: three times greater than in adjacent Ethiopia

qas.question: How much higher is the Somalia teledensity compared to Niger?
What percentage of the Somali telecommunications does Hormuud Telecom make up?

context: After forming partnerships with <a0_0>multinational corporations<a0_0/> such as Sprint, ITT and Telenor, these firms now offer the cheapest and clearest phone calls in Africa. These <a1_0><b5_0>Somali telecommunication companies<b5_0/><a1_0/> also provide services to every city, town and hamlet in Somalia. There are presently around <a2_0>25<a2_0/> mainlines per 1,000 persons, and the local availability of telephone lines (<a3_0>tele-density<a3_0/>) is higher than in neighboring countries; <b8_0>three times greater than in adjacent Ethiopia<b8_0/>. Prominent Somali telecommunications companies include <b7_0>Somtel Network, Golis Telecom Group, Hormuud Telecom, Somafone, Nationlink, Netco, Telcom and Somali Telecom Group<b7_0/>. Hormuud Telecom alone grosses about <a4_0><b6_0><b9_0>$40 million<b9_0/><b6_0/><a4_0/> a year. Despite their rivalry, several of these companies signed an interconnectivity deal in 2005 that allows them to set prices, maintain and expand their networks, and ensure that competition does not get out of control.
